context: Concentrations of 1,3,5-trimethylbenzene never exceeded the 0.5mg/l threshold reporting value established for the GC/MS method with surfactant solutions. As with PCE concentrations, Varsol™ concentrations were up to 10 times lower than had been expected based on model predictions. Since concentrations of Varsol™ marker compounds were always near the threshold reporting value of the analytical method, calculations of Varsol™ removal are less accurate and less precise than those for PCE. During the surfactant plateau region, decane removal averaged 56% and undecane removal averaged 33%. Based on the surfactant partitioning behavior of the Varsol™ marker compounds (measured separately by headspace chromatography at USEPA facilities), it is estimated that removal of 1,3,5-trimethylbenzene was likely around 70%. Average Varsol™ removal would certainly have exceeded 95% in the absence of surfactant due to the high vapor–liquid partitioning coefficients (Henry’s law constant) observed for the Varsol™ markers. Based on this vapor–liquid partitioning information, Varsol™ removal from water should exceed even that of PCE.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, decane and undecane are both mentioned as compounds whose removal efficiencies were evaluated during a surfactant plateau region. Decane removal averaged 56%, while undecane removal averaged 33%. This indicates a comparative analysis of their removal rates, suggesting that both compounds are relevant in the study of surfactant interactions and removal processes, although their specific interactions are not detailed.
llm_generation.reason: The score of 3 reflects a moderate relevance, as decane and undecane are compared in terms of their removal efficiencies in the context of surfactant behavior. However, there is no deeper exploration of their chemical interactions or significance beyond this comparative analysis.
